intro: Cordia guineensis subsp. mutica, commonly known as the African sand apple, is a small evergreen shrub or tree native to tropical Africa. It is characterized by its elliptical, leathery leaves that are arranged alternately along the stems. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in inflorescences, followed by fleshy, red or orange berries. The fruit is edible, with a sweet, acidic flavor, and is often consumed fresh or used in traditional medicine. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to dry or semi-arid environments.
